name: More Aussie Lingo Quiz | Varieties of English | 15 Questions

questions.text: If you're cooking up some 'bum nuts', what might your family soon have the pleasure of eating?
questions.explanation:
Eggs.

	Just like 'cackle berries', 'bum nuts' are chook eggs!

questions.text: If you're out and about and spot a 'deadly treadly', what have you seen?
questions.explanation:
A bicycle.

	Have you ever come a gutser off a bicycle, I have, and 'deadly treadly' is a 'bloody' good description - I 'buggered' my 'good' knee when my then five year old son rode in front of me and I went arse over t*t, off my bike!

Underpants.

	Scungy dungs or scungy dungers - terrible sounding, but they're just underpants, well, specifically, mens underpants - get the picture?

questions.text: What does the phrase, 'what do you think this is, bush week' mean?
questions.explanation:
A term of incredulity.

	The Macquarie Dictionary states that 'bush week' is, "a fictitious week when country people come to town", and, "circumstances in which unsuspecting people are imposed upon."  I always ask my kids if they think it's 'bush week' when they ask for something that's way out of line - like a $400+ X-box for Christmas!

questions.text: If you're as 'mad as a cut snake' what are you?
questions.explanation:
Very angry.

	You're very angry and upset, likely to 'lose your cool', 'spit the dummy' or even 'chuck a wobbly'!  Can also mean crazy 'as a loon'!

questions.text: If I said I didn't like your 'clobber', what would I be criticising?
questions.explanation:
Your clothes.

	The Macquarie Dictionary states, 'clobber' - "clothes or gear, Sunday clobber" - 19th century British slang, origin unknown.

questions.text: If you're a 'cacky hander', what are you?
options: A person of the Kiwi persuasion
questions.explanation:
A left handed person.

	Just like a 'goofy footer ', which is a lefty surfer, a 'cacky hander' is a left handed person.  Statistics show that lefties make up about 10% of the population.

An empty beer bottle.

	After a party or a big night on the 'grog' you're going to have a squillion 'dead marines' to dispose of.

questions.text: 'I'll fix the Jack and Jill', means what?
questions.explanation:
I'll pay the bill.

	Usually in a restaurant, you state you'll pay the bill for the meal.

questions.text: If someone says you're 'a long drink of water', what are you?
questions.explanation:
Very tall.

	Just like 'you'd have to run around the shower to get wet' meaning you're as skinny as, 'a long drink of water' means you're very tall!

A mess.

	From the yiddish, shlim mazel -  a person who always has bad luck.  A 'shemozzle' is a colloquial term for a confused state of affairs, a muddle, a mess, an uproar, a row !

questions.text: If you're 'a sick puppy' what are you?
questions.explanation:
You're depraved.

	To be 'a sick puppy' is to be a very depraved, 'sick' person!

questions.text: If you're called a 'scrubber', what does it mean?
questions.correct: You're an ugly, rough, or immoral girl
options: You're as useful as a dishwashing implement
questions.explanation:
You're an ugly, rough, or immoral girl.

	A derogatory term for an ugly or unkempt girl or woman, or a girl/woman with 'loose' morals or 'rough' behaviour, where I am from.

questions.correct: A week's holiday at the end of studies
questions.explanation:
A week's holiday at the end of studies.

	A week or so of holidays for, specifically, Year 12 students, usually at Surfers Paradise, Queensland, or some other place in the sun, taken after their final exams - my eldest is experiencing 'schoolies' weel' in 2002!

options: Busy time at a pig farm
questions.explanation:
Hectic beer drinking session.

	Formerly in New South Wales, specifically, this was a hectic session of buying and drinking beers by men in pubs near to closing time, which from 1916 to 1955 was, for many hotels, 6 pm.
